Row.Text: Though today a republic, the island of Iceland has undergone drastic changes throughout its history. To begin with, it was colonised by Norse settlers, giving it a ready-made bastion of culture. Over the years to come, Iceland became a Commonwealth under Danish rule, with a successful parliament, the Althing, among the first in the world. Following this time of prosperity came the Sturlung Wars, which ravaged the island and made it ever more reliant on Denmark. A colony of the Dano-Norwegian Empire, Iceland failed to achieve much until it became independent after the Second World War, due to the Allied takeover of the island - it subsequently voted to become a republic, and prospered to years afterwards. However, as a result of corrupt financial policy, Iceland sank into a deep recession, and is only just emerging from these dark days.

Ingólfur Arnarson and his wife Hallveig are recognized as the first permanent Nordic settlers of Iceland. According to Landnáma he built his homestead in (and gave name to) Reykjavík in 874. Although recent archaeological finds in Iceland suggest settlement may have started a little earlier, the date is probably not too far off.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The medieval chronicler Ari Thorgilsson said Ingólfr was the first Nordic settler in Iceland, but mentioned that "Papar" - i.e. Irish monks and hermits - had been in the country before the Norsemen. He wrote that they left because they did not want to live amongst the newly arrived Norse pagans.

Ingolfur Arnarson, great chieftain and first settler of Iceland, your noble kin await your command. Following your expulsion from Norway, you would seek out the path of your ancestors, and by the will of the Gods you would establish the first Nordic settlement in Iceland in 874 A.D. Iceland is an ancient nation, with a long history of parlimentary tradition chronicled in her great, epic sagas. Though subject to Norway and then Denmark throughout the first millenium, through the perserverance of your people's nordic spirit, Iceland would gain its independence in the middle of the 20th century, and has since continued the democratic traditions of her noble ancestors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Heroic viking, great poems have yet to tell the tale of your return, and the coming deeds of your people will serve to inspire their Skaldic verses. Can you uphold the legacy of your ancestors? Can you sail the ferocious seas in search of lands which would bring glory to your name? Can you build a civilization that can stand the test of time?
Earn [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Writer points from defeating enemy naval units. Receive a free Skald upon discovering Writing.
Contains a slot for a Great Work of Writing.

A thing was the governing assembly in Germanic societies and introduced into some Celtic societies, made up of the free people of the community and presided over by lawspeakers, meeting in a place called a thingstead. Today, the term lives on in the official names of national legislatures and political and judicial institutions in the Nordic countries, in the Manx form tyn, as a term for the three legislative bodies on the Isle of Man, and in the English term husting.

+2 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness when [ICON_CONNECTED] Connected to or in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital. +10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when constructing buildings. Naval trade routes originating from this city have a 50% increase in range. Contains a slot for a Great Work of Writing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Monument.

The Thingstead is the Icelandic unique building, replacing the Amphitheater. The Thingstead increases the civilization's [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness when [ICON_CONNECTED] Connected to or in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital and increases the [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output of this city. The Thingstead increases the [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production output of this city when constructing buildings and increases the range of Naval trade routes leaving this city. Contains a slot for a Great Work of Writing. Can only be built if this city contains a Monument.

The term skald (or skáld) meaning 'poet', is generally used for poets who composed at the courts of Scandinavian and Icelandic leaders during the Viking Age and Middle Ages. Skaldic poetry forms one of two main groupings of Old Norse poetry, the other being the anonymous Eddic poetry.

The Skald is the Icelandic unique unit, replacing the Great Writer. The Skald can embark and enter Ocean tiles and receives a +100% Defense Bonus and moves at double the rate while embarked. The Skald may found a city on a foreign continent. Cities founded by Skalds start with a prefilled Great Work of Writing slot and start with a free Worker.

Unique Icelandic Great Writer that can embark and enter Ocean tiles and receives a defense bonus and moves at double the rate while embarked. The Skald may found a city on a foreign continent that starts with a prefilled Great Work of Writing slot and a free Worker.
Vilið Hrafnketill heyra,[NEWLINE]hvé hreingróit steini[NEWLINE]Þrúðar skalk ok þengil[NEWLINE]þjófs ilja blað leyfa.
A verse about the giant Þjazi
Hinn es varp á víða[NEWLINE]vinda ǫndurdísar[NEWLINE]of manna sjǫt margra[NEWLINE]mundlaug fǫður augum.
An exchange of verses between Bragi and a troll-woman
Skǫld kalla mik:[NEWLINE]skipsmið Viðurs,[NEWLINE]Gauts gjafrǫtuð,[NEWLINE]grepp óhneppan,[NEWLINE]Yggs ǫlbera,[NEWLINE]óðs skap-Móða,[NEWLINE]hagsmið bragar.[NEWLINE]Hvat's skald nema þat?
The forehead-moon of the formidable friend of gods shone; the renowned god aimed terrifying glances at the necklace of the earth.
On a good day[NEWLINE]will such a king be born[NEWLINE]who leaves such a sorrow.[NEWLINE]His reign[NEWLINE]will forever be[NEWLINE]mentioned as good only.
When time was young,[NEWLINE]where Ymir dwelt,[NEWLINE]was no sand, no sea,[NEWLINE]nor cool waves;[NEWLINE]earth existed not,[NEWLINE]nor heaven above,[NEWLINE]A chasm gaped,[NEWLINE]and no grass.
Love for a liege lord burns hot; and it is well that I will not be fighting against the king's luck.

The whole race of men to win[NEWLINE]Óðinn's grace has wrought poems[NEWLINE](I recall the exquisite[NEWLINE]works of my forebears);[NEWLINE]but with sorrow, for well did[NEWLINE]Viðrir's [Óðinn's] power please the poet,[NEWLINE]do I conceive hate for the first husband of[NEWLINE]Frigg [Óðinn], now I serve Christ.

Thus spake my mother[NEWLINE]That for me should they buy[NEWLINE]A barque and beauteous oars[NEWLINE]To go forth with vikings.[NEWLINE]Stand in the stern,[NEWLINE]Steer a dear vessel,[NEWLINE]Hold course for a haven,[NEWLINE]Hew down many foemen.

Hilmir réð á heiði,[NEWLINE]hjaldrseiðs, þrimu, galdra[NEWLINE]óðr við œskimeiða[NEWLINE]ey vébrautar, heyja,[NEWLINE]áðr gnapsólar Gripnis[NEWLINE]gnýstœrandi fœri[NEWLINE]rausnarsamr til rimmu[NEWLINE]ríðviggs lagar skíðum.
Vestr komk of ver,[NEWLINE]en ek Viðris ber[NEWLINE]munstrandar mar,[NEWLINE]svá 's mitt of far;[NEWLINE]drók eik á flot[NEWLINE]við ísabrot;[NEWLINE]hlóðk mærðar hlut[NEWLINE]munknarrar skut.
Varð framgengt,[NEWLINE]þars Fróði bjó,[NEWLINE]feigðar orð,[NEWLINE]es at Fjǫlni kom;[NEWLINE]siklingi[NEWLINE]svigðis geira[NEWLINE]vágr vindlauss[NEWLINE]of viða skyldi.

Hilmir réð á heiði[NEWLINE]hjaldrskíðs þrimu, galdra[NEWLINE]óðr við œskimeiða[NEWLINE]ey vébrautar, heyja,[NEWLINE]áðr gnapsalar Gripnis[NEWLINE]gnýstœrandi fœri[NEWLINE]rausnarsamr til rimmu[NEWLINE]ríðviggs lagar skíðum.

The sun knew not[NEWLINE]where she had housing;[NEWLINE]The moon knew not[NEWLINE]what Might he had;[NEWLINE]The stars knew not[NEWLINE]where stood their places.[NEWLINE]Thus was it ere[NEWLINE]the earth was fashioned.
Now is the flight of eagles[NEWLINE]Over the field; the sailors[NEWLINE]Of the sea-horses hie them[NEWLINE]To the Hanged-God's gifts and feasting.

Onto the keel you climb,[NEWLINE]Cold is the ocean brine.[NEWLINE]Keeping courage though,[NEWLINE]Locked in a deadly throe.[NEWLINE]Baldhead, show no fear,[NEWLINE]showers fall on you here.[NEWLINE]With maidens you had a way,[NEWLINE]All must die one day.
Vásöflugr réð vísi[NEWLINE]Ok sás æzt gat ríki[NEWLINE]Húf lét hilmir svífa[NEWLINE]Getk þess es gramr fór vitja[NEWLINE]Sætt frák Dæla dróttin.

Mágnús hlýð til máttigs óðar,[NEWLINE]mangi veit ek fremra annan;[NEWLINE]yppa ráðumk yðru kappi,[NEWLINE]Jóta gramr, í kvæði fljótu.[NEWLINE]Haukr réttr es þú, Hörða dróttinn,[NEWLINE]hverr gramr es þér stórum verri,[NEWLINE]meiri verði þinn an þeira[NEWLINE]þrifnuðr allr, unz himinn rifnar.

The king's sharp sword lies clean and bright,[NEWLINE]Our brave king is to Russia gone, -- Prepared in foreign lands to fight:[NEWLINE]Braver than he on earth there's none; Our ravens croak to have their fill,[NEWLINE]His sharp sword will carve many feast The wolf howls from the distant hill.[NEWLINE]To wolf and raven in the East.

Hratt lítt gamall, lýtir[NEWLINE]lögreiðar, framm skeiðum;[NEWLINE]fórat fylkir œri[NEWLINE]folksveimuðr þér heiman;[NEWLINE]hilmir bjótt ok hættir[NEWLINE]harðbrynjuð skip kynjum;[NEWLINE]reiðr hafðir þú rauðar[NEWLINE]randir Knútr fyr landi.
Jǫfurr heyri upphaf,[NEWLINE]ofrask mun konungs lof[NEWLINE](hǫ́ttu nemi hann) rétt,[NEWLINE]hróðrs sins (bragar míns).
Gjöld hefk marka[NEWLINE]malmdyns fyr hlyn[NEWLINE]fram fimm tøgu[NEWLINE]forvíst borit,[NEWLINE]þeiras veitti[NEWLINE]víghagr fyr brag[NEWLINE]mér morðstœrir,[NEWLINE]mann-Baldr, es ek fann.

Hugstóra biðk heyra,[NEWLINE]hressfœrr jöfurr, þessar,[NEWLINE]þolðak vás, hvé vísur,[NEWLINE]verðung, of för gerðak.[NEWLINE]Sendr vask upp af öndrum[NEWLINE]austr, svafk fátt í hausti,[NEWLINE]til Svíþjóðar, síðan,[NEWLINE]svanvangs í för langa.
Even as Ari Thorgilson the Learned, the Priest,[NEWLINE]Hath told it, who was the man of all Iceland[NEWLINE]Most learned in tales of the land's inhabiting[NEWLINE]And in lore of time agone.

The ring-linked coat of strongest mail[NEWLINE]Could not withstand the iron hail,[NEWLINE]Though sewed with care and elbow bent,[NEWLINE]By Norn, on its strength intent.[NEWLINE]The fire of battle raged around, --[NEWLINE]Odin's steel shirt flew all unbound![NEWLINE]The earl his ring-mail from him flung,[NEWLINE]Its steel rings on the wet deck rung;[NEWLINE]Part of it fell into the sea, --[NEWLINE]A part was kept, a proof to be[NEWLINE]How sharp and thick the arrow-flight[NEWLINE]Among the sea-steeds in this fight.[NEWLINE]
"What kind of kingdom is that," said the king, "which I can give[NEWLINE]to Harald, that I may possess Denmark entire?"[NEWLINE]"It is Norway," said the earl.

Farið til Fýrisvallar,[NEWLINE]folka tungls, hverr's hungrar,[NEWLINE]vörðr, at virkis garði[NEWLINE]vestr kveldriðu hesta;[NEWLINE]þar hefr hreggdrauga höggvit[NEWLINE](hóllaust es þat) sólar[NEWLINE]elfar skíðs fyr ulfa[NEWLINE]Eiríkr í dyn geira.

and thus the swift hastener of battle, Þröng's old friend, greedily drank the raised drink of the molten lump in the air with the swift mouths of his hands [caught it in his grasp], when the hissing cinder took flight from the hostile breast of the grip [palm] of the ardent lover of Hrímnir's maiden [giant] towards the one who strongly misses Þrúðr.

Brightly beamed the lights-of-[NEWLINE]both-her-cheeks upon me—[NEWLINE]e'er will I recall it—[NEWLINE]o'er the heaped-up wood-pile;[NEWLINE]and the instep saw I[NEWLINE]of the shapely woman—[NEWLINE]no laughing matter, lo! my[NEWLINE]longing—by the threshold.
Mjǫk erum tregt[NEWLINE]tungu at hrœra[NEWLINE]með loptvétt[NEWLINE]ljóðpundara;[NEWLINE]esa nú vænligt[NEWLINE]of Viðurs þýfi,[NEWLINE]né hógdrœgt[NEWLINE]ór hugar fylgsni.
